content.webTitle: In praise of… Mark Damazer | Editorial

fields.headline: In praise of… Mark Damazer
fields.bodyText: Anyone put in charge of a broadcasting landmark like Radio 4 is prey to two big temptations. The first is to go for gimmickry – to ring the changes with a plethora of sex weeks and other wacky commissions. The other is to go downmarket, and follow BBC2 into a morass of gardening and cookery programmes. It is to the eternal credit of Mark Damazer – who announced yesterday that he would step down as controller of Radio 4 in September – that he took neither perilous path. Perhaps the thought did not detain him long: Mr Damazer is after all the sort of man even clever colleagues describe as a "bulging brain", and has been known to spin out press interviews to diary-shredding lengths just so he can rhapsodise about his favourite historians (he read history at Cambridge and took a double starred first). Instead, over six years at the helm of Radio 4, he has livened up the station – but ever so gently. He has brought in fresh presenters (Evan Davis to Today, Jane Garvey on Woman's Hour, Kirsty Young on Desert Island Discs) and nifty new programmes (Americana, A History of the World in 100 Objects) – and informed the schedules with his current-affairs experience. There are some areas in which he could have gone further – Radio 4's presentation is an all-white enclave, and Quote ... Unquote should surely have been put down by now – but Mr Damazer has otherwise been an ambitious yet self-effacing channel controller – the sort of bureaucrat who gives the BBC a good name.
